October 17, 1936. 8ir, With reference to ay despatch Ho.41 of May 25, 1936, regarding the disposal of a sun of 1 Iraqi ainaru 110/433 held by ae on deposit In respect of the balance remaining from the donation of Raja Mohaaaed Khushalbai to the shrine at Kerbala, I hare the honour to report that I have to-day paid this amount to Qhulam All Rajamohamaed Panjetoni on hie producing to me a Succession Certificate granted by the First Class Sub-Judge of Ahmedabad. s Majesty's Principal Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Foreign Office, London, S. W. 1. I have the honour to be with the highest respect Sir, Your most obedient humble servant (Sad.) c. A. W. Were. GAW/SS(K 6643/2789/293) No.41. His Majesty’s Consul at Bagdad presents his compliments to H.M. Principal Secretary of State for Pbreign Affairs, Foreign Office, London, S.W.l. and has the honour to transmit to him the under-mentioned documents. British Consulate, Bagdad. May 25, 1936. Reference to previous correspondences Foreign Office despatch No.31 of April 30, 1936. (K 4527/2789/293) Description of Enclosure. Name and Date. To Ghulam Ali R.Panjetani, and others. No.5/12 dated May 25, 1936. Subject. Money held at Bagdad Consulate on behalf of Raja Mohammad Khushalbai.(K 6643/2789/293) No.5/12. British Consulate, Bagdad. 25th May, 1936. Sir, I have to refer to my previous communications to you, dated February 25, and March 16, 1936, on the subject of your viish to secure the payment to C.R.Panjetani of the sum of Rs. 1472/7/-, originally received by me for the account of Raja Mohamed Khushalbai, and connected matters. 2. As I am anxious to disburse this sum as soon as possible to tne person or persons entitled to receive it, I should be grateful if you would take early steps to furnish me with the documents wnich I require, that is to say, a certificate from the competent Indian Court establishing the status of the persons claiming to be the heirs of the late Raja Mohammed Khushalbhai; and, if payment is to be made to some person other than the heirs, a document authorising such person to receive payment and to give full discharge on behalf of the heirs. I am, etc., (Sd.) C.A.W. Here. H.M. Consul. Ghulam Ali R.Panjetani and others, Near Caikwar’s Haveli, Ahmadabad.X In any furtW^o«uminicat,ion on this/object, pi and addrS^s —not to any person by itame’hwt' ^^✓Under-Secretary of State,” Foreign Office, London, S.W. 1. n / i <i j 1 A/* S' 5 \ 2950 I ^/- i v S LW38 J f THE Under-Secretary of State for^ Foreign'Affairs presents his n compliments to siy t an< ^’ by direction of the Secretary of State, transmits herewith cop W of the under-mentioned paper. 7 dZJ 193^ Foreign Office fl V n X . INDIA OFFICENo. 26. r O Q c; 'Y i cL. \J <j vJ \ Britl Ah OojiBUiitte j Bagdad. March 51, 1936. Sir, I have the honour to refer to your despatch No. 1? of March 16 (K 2789/2789/293) on the subject of a suia of Iraqi dinars 110/433 deposited at this post in the name of Raja Mohamed Khushalbai. 2 . I have recently been in direct communication on this subject with the alleged heirs of Raja Mohamed Khushalbai, and have informed them that I will deliver the sum in question to them or to any agent appointed by them, on their satisfying me that they are the persons entitled at law to receive it. I have no doubt that they will be able so to satisfy me in due course, when it will be open to them to request the local authorities to use the money for the purposes described in their letter of January 31 addressed to the India office. I have the honour to be with the highest respect, Sir, Your most obedient humble servant. His Majesty’s Principal secretary of State for Foreign Affaire, Foreign Office, London, 8.W.1* /C\Draft Paper. t ^ 7?/ Department, 4599 5000 2.36 u. s.s., F.O. INDIA OFFICE 4 15 ^Pfi 1936 Sir, I am directed by the Secretary of State for India to refer to Foreign Office letter of April 2nd, No.K.3538/ 2789/293, and connected correspondence regarding the sum held on deposit at the Bagdad Consulate in respect of the unexpended balance of money given by Raja Mohammed Khushalbai for provision O' of an electric light system at Kerb^la. Attention is invited in this connection to the papers which were forwarded under India Office printed letter of 9th April, No.P.Z.£342/36. It will be observed that the enclosure to the Government of Bombay* s letter of 26th February, No.0/2604-B, is a copy of the letter which was forwarded to the Foreign Office under India Office Memorandum of 20th March, No. P. Z.1928/36. Subject:- Disposal of the Balance or donation g i ve n By Ha j a N oh ame d idiu s ha IB h a i for provision of an electric light system at Kerb ala. Sir, I am directed By the Governor in Council to refer to the correspondence ending with my letter Ko.Q/1711-B, dated the 7 th instant, on the subject mentioned above, and to forward for such action as the Government of India consider necessary an endorsment from the Collector of Ahmedabad Ho.lfSO. , dated the 5 th Hebruary 1936, together with a latter from the three sons of the late Baja fohamed hhushalbhai, dated the 31st January x9oo, regard ing the transfer of the l us afar ah an a at Hucha-uay ab, Kerb ala, to their names. The Under Secretary of State for India ■d resents Ms conipllraents to the Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs# ando with reference to India Office letter of 29th February No* f.2.1350/36* begs to forward for tranaMssion to the appropriate authority a further com-unlcation receive ; throu^i the Coliectoi*, Ahuedabad, and a copy of a letter# / with enclosures# from the OeTtiranent o a# OoTesimeiiS of XnHa TefEef Jregardlns the dleposal of a suri held of 27 th February# io«F 1- 7 36 ) with enelosuree* }on deposit at Bagdad Consulate in ) 7 respect of 'unexpended balance of noney given by Ka^a Mohamod KhusMlbai for the provision of an electric light system at Kerbala. IFF I r OFFICF, 3 . W* X* * 20th Hareh# 1936.toP.Z. 1928/36 enclosure in the High Coiamissioner for India* s covering note dated 16th March 1936 near gaikwar’s haveli AHMEDABAD, INDIA. 14th -^ehruary 1936 'IS a I* 'Z. t ■< —i - r-i ■ ;h Coumiissioner of India, a Office, Whitehall, London* Sir, I the under-signed Gulamahhaa Rajemohomed panjetani, an inhabitant of Ahaedabad, Bombay Presidency, most humbly and* respectfully beg to submit the following few lines under your honour’s kihd consideration. I humbly beg to state Sir that ay father Rajemohaxaed Xhushalbhai has given the above contribution in the Holy Shrines of Hazarat Abbas & Hazarat Hussein in the year 1932* The above sum was sent through The Collector of Ahmedabad and deposited in the Imperial Bank of Persia, Baghdad on the 19th October 1922, on the name of Electrical Installation Fund. We have been informed recently by the India Office, Whitehall, London, ref* P.Z.7674/35 through the Collector of Ahmedabad to the effect that there is still a balance of Ss. 1472/7/- out of Rs.25,000, requesting us to state as how this balance should be utilized*\ 2 . ¥e have called accordingly by the Collector of Ahraedabad and we have given a written statement that the amount in question should be utilized for the repair works of the Musafarkhana, which is purchased by our deceased father on 12*1.1922; and if there be any balance still we intend to putting in Electrical Installation in the said Musaf arkhana, and that amount should be utilized for that work. We have received an urgent letter from our servant named Mahomed Ameen Hindi, who is residing in the same Musafarkhana, requesting us that our Musafarkhana is in a worst condition and it must get repaired immediately, and therefore we are arranging our Brother to go to Karbala in the next month for the repair works of the Musafarkhana. He will do everything which is necessary for the repair works of the Musafarkhana; and therefore according to our written statement through the Collector of Ahmedabad to H.E. The High Commissioner for Iraq, Baghdad, we hope your honour will be kind enough- to hand over the balanced sun Hs. 1472/7/- to our brother who will be leaving for Baghdad in the next month,, or your honour may use the sum directly for the repair works of the Musafarkhana. H.E. The High Commissioner of Iraq has helped us very much in the past and all the work has been done by his honour’s kind help to us and we are extremely thankful and highly obliged for it, and moreover we trust that our brother Gr.R.Panjetani, will be granted your honour’s kind and favourable interview and the help whenever he requires for the carrying out the above work. Hoping to be excused for the troubles and awaiting your honour’s early reply in this connection. I beg, etc., Sgd.Gulamabbas Rajemohomed Panjetani. Through: The collector of Ahraedabad, Ahmedabaa. (INDIA).«■*) II t \!< ' • & CX b * 2^ I No.F.l-N/36. M . Z*. ! 1864 /WM' 1 — 1 ('. o £»' ? From , ‘ ^ The Foreign Secretary to the Government of India. To The Under Secretary of State for India Political Department, LONDON. Dated New Delhi, the ‘X'j 1 ^ February 1936. Subject:- Disposal of the balance of donation given by Haja Mohamed Khushalbhai for provision of an electric light system at Kerbala. Sir, • With reference to India Office letter No.P-Z- 7674/35, dated the 8 th November 1935 I am directed to forward a copy of a letter from the Government of Bombay, No.O/1711-B, dated the 7th February 1936, with enclosures and to state that the Government of India agree to the suggestion made therein. I have the honour to be, Sir, Your most obedient servant, (3-k. for Foreign Secretary to the ^overnme^of Cl • ' v %+p) 16 MAR 1936 - _ j ffice. 1864 Copy of letter from the Chief.Secretary J \ • r- '.'i J to the Government of Bombay tT'tM' Foreign Secretary to the Government of India, No.0/1711-B dated the 7th February 1936. Subject:- Disposal of the balance of donation given by Raja.Mohamed Khushalbhai for provision of an electric light system at Karbala. With reference to Mr. Hill’s letter No. D.6G23-N/35, dated the 24th December 1935, I am directed by the Governor in Council to forward a copy of a letter from the Collector of Ahmedabad No.M.S.C-, dated the 29th January 1936, together with its accompaniment ^ 1 ^ 4 ^ 4 ^^ and to observe that the Government of Bombay see no objection to the balance of Rs.1,472-7-0 being utilised as sug gested by Raja Mohamed Khushalbhai’s three sons in their joint statement. Ilb % Copy of a letter from the Collector of Ahmedabad No.M.S.C., dated the 29th January 1936 Subject:- Balance of donation paid by Baja Maharnad Khushalbhai. Disposal of - at Kerbs.la. With reference to your No.0/132-B dated EXXXX 8*1.1936 I have the honour to state that the donor Raja Mahamad Khushalbhai expired on 20.2.1931. His three sons were called and consulted in the matter. They state that the balance of Rs.1,472-7-0 may be utilized in repairing a 'Musafarkhana* erected at the ex pense of the donor for the temporary residence for pilgrims at Kerbala. I see no objection to the proposal. 2. Their joint statement is appended herewith.We, Gulamali Rajemuhammed, aged about 33 years, Mornna by caste, merchant by occupation, Gulam Muhammad Rajemuhammad resident of the same place, aged about 28 years, Mornna by caste, occupation the same, and Gulam Abbas Rajemuham- mad, resident of the same place, aged about 24 years, Momna by caste and occupation the same, appear in person and on being questioned state that our father, Rajemuhammad Khushalbhai, died in 1931 (on 20.2.1931), and we three brothers are his heirs. C#r father had donated Rs.25,000 in 1922 for the purpose of electric installation in mosques at Kerbala, and a balance of Rs.WZfl/- has remained out of it. On being questioned in connection with this balance we desire that it should be spent towards the repairs of a Musa- farkhana purchased at Kerbala by our father in 1921, which is situated in the lane called Kachaye Nayab, is managed by us three brothers through a servant employed by us and is used by pilgrims going from here for residential purposes free of charge. The musafarkhana is not in a good condition at present and is in need of urgent repairs. It is, therefore, desirable that the amount should be spent for a charitable purpose in the manner expressed by us. What is stated above has been read over to us and is correct. We add that in case an^ balance is left from the soid^after the expenses towards the repairs of the said Musafarkhana are paid, we desire that it should be spent on the electric installation, etc. What is stated above is correct. Dated 17.1.36. Slfn |efo?e in En6llsh Sd. R.S.Vyas Mamlatdar.2? o P.Z*1350/36. Near Gaikwars Haveli, AHMEDABAD. 31st January 1936 The High Commissioner for India, India Office, vtfhitehall, London. Sir, Reference your No. P.Z. 7674/35. We have just received information through the Collector of Ahmedabad regarding the amount of As.1472/7/- has been carried over as balance out of the amount of As.25,000 given in donation to the Holy Shrines of Hazarat Abbas and Hazarat Hussein, by our deceased father; and were asked by the Collector of Ahmedabad to state as to how this amount should be utilised. In connection with the remaining amount of Rs.1472/7/- we have stated that the amount should be utilised for repair works of the Musafarkhana, which was purchased by our deceased father on 20.2.1922; and if there be any saving it should be utilized in Electrical Installation in the same property. While thanking your honour and awaiting your honour’s early orders in this matter, We jointly beg to remain, etc. (Sd.) (1) GULAMALI R. PANJETANI. (2) GULAMMOHOMED RAJEMDHOMED PANJETANI. (3) GULAMABBAS RAJLMOHOMED PANJETANI. Through The Collector of Ahmedabad, Ahmedabad, India.In any further communication on this subject, please quota No. K 2. and address— not to any person by name, but to— “The Under-Secretary of State,’’ Foreign Office, London, S.W. 1. f Mr*) * THE Under - Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs presents Ins and begs to enquire, by direction of the Secretary of State, whether an answer may shortly be expected to the Foreign Office letter No. K MSOq./«S0^ X, 5 2Afct- (b respecting (Uv-out at (<X)o.<l<LcuL CxUuJLat ^ f u^^LeJl tUic f ^ ’ A a™ C^cfccc. w.t (IAAJ_ of the <jw CP— COPY SEMT EY AIR MAIL Of 3FfB~r-—— Foreign Office, ^lU-2-i , 193C. 17 —6450 A II4S6 ' dLj. l VSTiWDEX£P In any further communication on this subject, please y No. K 11501+ //isot+l 2 ^^) and address —not to any person by name, but to— The Under-Secretary of State, Foreign Office, London, S.W. 1 . (3 Ft THE Under-Secretary of State for Foreign' Affairs presents his compliments to yjQ and ’ by direction of Secretary of State, transimts herewith cop/^i of the under-mentioned paper for such observations as may desire to offer, ^ Foreign Office, O 193o. vit- Reference to previous correspondence : Description of Enclosure. Name and Date. Subject. «}C <§xisv^ -Acid- Cit QdiiuAlaM^ fat ^ ^ Caft (jtt tyeAiato-. . Similar letter sent tof Jt u Copy. (K 11504/11504/293) r I / 4 33 935 Memo randum. In September, 1922, Raja Mohamed Khushalbai, of Ahmedabad (Bombay Presidency) made an offer, through the High Commission, of Rs.25,000/-, for the provision of an electric light system at Kerbala. The money was actually received in November, 1922. Independently of this offer, the concession for the supply of electric light in Kerbala was obtained by an association of curious composition, with aims partly commercial and partly benevolent; and it was decided to devote Raja Mohamed Khushalbai’s donation to the provision of electrical equipment in the Shrines of Abbas and Hussein. Nothing was settled as to payment of the cost of current consumed, and certain R.M.K. did not contemplate an endowment in perpetuity; no one else had any ideas on the subject: and for some reason, not at present apparent, the Shrines have drawn, and continue to draw, free current, to the detriment of the concessionaires. The net amount received from India was Es. 24,996/14/- (November, 1922). This sum was transferred, in April, 1925, to the Examiner of Irrigation and Public V?orks ('Irag Government), the Ministry of Communications and Public Works having undertaken to carry out the necessary work and to submit a statement of the expenditure incurred in due course up to January 5, 1929, the Ministry had expended Es. 25,524/7/-, and they then reoue..ted the High Commissioner to take over the balance of Es. 1,472/7/- as it was contrary to regulations for them to hold sums on deposit for long periods. They suggested that the balance should be held by the High Commissioner against the cost of possible future repairs to the installation. The

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: PZ 7674/35 Iraq: disposal of the balance of a donation given by Raja Mohamed Khushalbai for provision of an electric light system at Kerbala

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence for this description commences at f 1, and terminates at f 35, it is the fifth file in a larger physical volume, each file has its own foliation sequence; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 1-35; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: The file concerns the disposal of a sum held on deposit at Bagdad Consulate in respect of the unexpended balance of money given by Raja Mohamed Khushalbai of Ahmedabad (Bombay Presidency) for the provision of an electric light system at shrines in Kerbala [Karbalā']. It consists of correspondence and a memorandum.The main correspondents are: the three sons of Raja Mohammed Khushalbai - Gulamali Rajemahomed Panjetani, Gulammohomed Rajemahomed Panjetani, and Gulamabbas Rajemahomed Panjetani; the British Consul, Bagdad [Baghdad]; the Collector of Ahmedabad; the Secretary to the Government of Bombay, General Department; the Chief Secretary to the Government of Bombay, Political and Reforms Department; the Foreign Secretary to the Government of India; the Under Secretary of State for India; and the Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs.The file contains multiple spellings for the persons mentioned as follows:Raja Mohamed Khushalbai (Raja Mohammed Khushalbai, Rajemuhammad Khushalbhai, Rajemohamed Khushalbhai, Rajemahomed Khushalbhai, Raja Mahamad Khushalbhai, Raja Mohamed Khushalbhai);Gulamali Rajemahomed Panjetani (Gulamali Rajemahomed, Gulamali Rajemuhammad);Gulammohomed Rajemahomed Panjetani (Gulammahomed Rajemahomed, Gulam Muhammad Rajemuhammad);Gulamabbas Rajemahomed Panjetani (Gulamabbas Rajemahomed, Gulam Abbas R. Panjetani, Ghulam Ali Rajamohammed Panjetani, Gulamabbas Rajemohomed Panjetani, Gulamabbas Rajemohamed Panjetani, Gulam Abbas Rajemuhammad).

name.namePart: Government of Bombay, Collector of Ahmedabad

Government of Bombay, Political and Services Department
